sn22.86:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
sn22.86:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
sn22.86:1.1.comm: This discourse is also found at SN 44.2.

sn22.86:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā anurādho bhagavato avidūre araññakuṭikāyaṃ viharati.
sn22.86:1.2.eng: Now at that time Venerable Anurādha was staying not far from the Buddha in a wilderness hut.

sn22.86:1.3.pli: Atha kho sambahulā aññatitthiyā paribbājakā yenāyasmā anurādho tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā anurādhena saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
sn22.86:1.3.eng: Then several wanderers of other religions went up to Venerable Anurādha and exchanged greetings with him.

sn22.86:1.4.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā āyasmantaṃ anurādhaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn22.86:1.4.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side and said to him:

sn22.86:1.5.pli: “yo so, āvuso anurādha, tathāgato uttamapuriso paramapuriso paramapattipatto, taṃ tathāgato imesu catūsu ṭhānesu paññāpayamāno paññāpeti:
sn22.86:1.5.eng: “Reverend Anurādha, when a Realized One is describing a realized one—a supreme person, highest of people, who has reached the highest point—they describe them in these four ways:
sn22.86:1.5.comm: This makes it clear that in this context, “realized one” cannot be just any sentient being. See note on SN 16.12:1.4.

sn22.86:1.6.pli: ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā”ti?
sn22.86:1.6.eng: After death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists.”

sn22.86:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā anurādho te aññatitthiye paribbājake etadavoca:
sn22.86:2.1.eng: When they said this, Venerable Anurādha said to those wanderers:

sn22.86:2.2.pli: “yo so āvuso tathāgato uttamapuriso paramapuriso paramapattipatto taṃ tathāgato aññatra imehi catūhi ṭhānehi paññāpayamāno paññāpeti:
sn22.86:2.2.eng: “Reverends, when a Realized One is describing a realized one—a supreme person, highest of people, who has reached the highest point—they describe them other than these four ways:

sn22.86:2.3.pli: ‘hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā, ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vā”ti.
sn22.86:2.3.eng: After death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists.”

sn22.86:2.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā āyasmantaṃ anurādhaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn22.86:2.4.eng: When he said this, the wanderers said to him:

sn22.86:2.5.pli: “so cāyaṃ bhikkhu navo bhavissati acirapabbajito, thero vā pana bālo abyatto”ti.
sn22.86:2.5.eng: “This mendicant must be junior, recently gone forth, or else a foolish, incompetent senior mendicant.”

sn22.86:2.6.pli: Atha kho aññatitthiyā paribbājakā āyasmantaṃ anurādhaṃ navavādena ca bālavādena ca apasādetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃsu.
sn22.86:2.6.eng: Then, after rebuking Venerable Anurādha by calling him “junior” and “foolish”, the wanderers got up from their seats and left.

sn22.86:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmato anurādhassa acirapakkantesu tesu aññatitthiyesu paribbājakesu etadahosi:
sn22.86:3.1.eng: Soon after they had left, Anurādha thought:

sn22.86:3.2.pli: “sace kho maṃ te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā uttariṃ pañhaṃ puccheyyuṃ.
sn22.86:3.2.eng: “If those wanderers were to inquire further,

sn22.86:3.3.pli: Kathaṃ byākaramāno nu khvāhaṃ tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ vuttavādī ceva bhagavato assaṃ, na ca bhagavantaṃ abhūtena abbhācikkheyyaṃ, dhammassa cānudhammaṃ byākareyyaṃ, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo gārayhaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgaccheyyā”ti?
sn22.86:3.3.eng: how should I answer them so as to repeat what the Buddha has said, and not misrepresent him with an untruth? How should I explain in line with his teaching, so that there would be no legitimate grounds for rebuttal and criticism?”

sn22.86:4.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā anurādho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā anurādho bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn22.86:4.1.eng: Then Venerable Anurādha went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him all that had happened.

sn22.86:4.3.pli: Atha kho, bhante, sambahulā aññatitthiyā paribbājakā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu …pe… maṃ etadavocuṃ:

sn22.86:4.4.pli: ‘yo so, āvuso anurādha, tathāgato uttamapuriso paramapuriso paramapattipatto taṃ tathāgato imesu catūsu ṭhānesu paññāpayamāno paññāpeti—

sn22.86:4.5.pli: hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā, na hoti …

sn22.86:4.6.pli: hoti ca na ca hoti, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā’”ti?

sn22.86:5.1.pli: Evaṃ vuttāhaṃ, bhante, te aññatitthiye paribbājake etadavocaṃ:

sn22.86:5.2.pli: “yo so, āvuso, tathāgato uttamapuriso paramapuriso paramapattipatto, taṃ tathāgato aññatra imehi catūhi ṭhānehi paññāpayamāno paññāpeti:

sn22.86:5.4.pli: ‘neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā’ti vāti.

sn22.86:5.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā maṃ etadavocuṃ:

sn22.86:5.6.pli: ‘so cāyaṃ bhikkhu na vo bhavissati acirapabbajito thero vā pana bālo abyatto’ti.

sn22.86:5.7.pli: Atha kho maṃ, bhante, te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā navavādena ca bālavādena ca apasādetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃsu.

sn22.86:6.1.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, acirapakkantesu tesu aññatitthiyesu paribbājakesu etadahosi:

sn22.86:6.2.pli: ‘sace kho maṃ te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā uttariṃ pañhaṃ puccheyyuṃ.

sn22.86:6.3.pli: Kathaṃ byākaramāno nu khvāhaṃ tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ vuttavādī ceva bhagavato assaṃ, na ca bhagavantaṃ abhūtena abbhācikkheyyaṃ, dhammassa cānudhammaṃ byākareyyaṃ, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo gārayhaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgaccheyyā’”ti?

sn22.86:7.4.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.86:7.4.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.86:7.6.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn22.86:7.6.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn22.86:7.7.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn22.86:7.16.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’

sn22.86:8.2.eng: Do you regard a realized one as form?”

sn22.86:8.4.eng: “Do you regard a realized one as feeling …

sn22.86:9.2.eng: Do you regard a realized one as in form?”

sn22.86:9.4.eng: “Or do you regard a realized one as distinct from form?”

sn22.86:9.6.eng: “Do you regard a realized one as in feeling …

sn22.86:10.2.pli: rūpaṃ … vedanā … saññā … saṅkhārā … viññāṇaṃ tathāgatoti samanupassasī”ti?
sn22.86:10.2.eng: Do you regard a realized one as possessing form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”

sn22.86:11.2.pli: ayaṃ so arūpī … avedano … asaññī … asaṅkhāro … aviññāṇo tathāgatoti samanupassasī”ti?
sn22.86:11.2.eng: Do you regard a realized one as without form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”

sn22.86:12.1.pli: “Ettha ca te, anurādha, diṭṭheva dhamme saccato thetato tathāgate anupalabbhiyamāne kallaṃ nu te taṃ veyyākaraṇaṃ:
sn22.86:12.1.eng: “In that case, Anurādha, since a realized one is not found by you as a genuine fact in this very life, is it cogent for you to declare:

sn22.86:12.2.pli: ‘yo so, āvuso, tathāgato uttamapuriso paramapuriso paramapattipatto taṃ tathāgato aññatra imehi catūhi ṭhānehi paññāpayamāno paññāpeti—
sn22.86:12.2.eng: ‘Reverends, when a Realized One is describing a realized one—a supreme person, highest of people, who has reached the highest point—they describe them other than these four ways:

sn22.86:12.3.pli: hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā … na hoti … hoti ca na ca hoti … neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti vā’”ti?
sn22.86:12.3.eng: After death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists’?”

sn22.86:13.2.pli: Pubbe cāhaṃ, anurādha, etarahi ca dukkhañceva paññapemi, dukkhassa ca nirodhan”ti.
sn22.86:13.2.eng: In the past, as today, what I describe is suffering and the cessation of suffering.”
sn22.86:13.2.comm: The particle c’eva here has its normal role of slight emphasis in conjunctions, and so this phrase does not mean, “I only teach suffering and the end of suffering”. The point, rather, is that when he speaks of cessation, it is the cessation of suffering, not the cessation of an “existing being”. This saying is also at MN 75:16.1 and SN 44.2:17.13.

sn22.87:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn22.87:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

sn22.87:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā vakkali kumbhakāranivesane viharati ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
sn22.87:1.2.eng: Now at that time Venerable Vakkali was staying in a potter’s shed, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn22.87:1.2.comm: Vakkali’s verses describe his perseverance in the face of illness (Thag 5.8), for which he was said to be the foremost in commitment to faith (AN 1.208, Snp 5.19:16.1).

sn22.87:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vakkali upaṭṭhāke āmantesi:

sn22.87:1.4.pli: “etha tumhe, āvuso, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamatha; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatha:
sn22.87:1.4.eng: “Please, reverends, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:

sn22.87:1.5.pli: ‘vakkali, bhante, bhikkhu ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno, so bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī’ti.
sn22.87:1.5.eng: ‘Sir, the mendicant Vakkali is sick, suffering, and gravely ill. He bows with his head to your feet.’

sn22.87:1.7.pli: ‘sādhu kira, bhante, bhagavā yena vakkali bhikkhu tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.
sn22.87:1.7.eng: ‘Sir, please go to the mendicant Vakkali out of sympathy.’”

sn22.87:1.8.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato vakkalissa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn22.87:1.8.eng: “Yes, reverend,” those monks replied. They did as he asked.

sn22.87:1.9.pli: “vakkali, bhante, bhikkhu ābādhiko dukkhito bāḷhagilāno, so bhagavato pāde sirasā vandati;

sn22.87:1.11.pli: ‘sādhu kira, bhante, bhagavā yena vakkali bhikkhu tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.

sn22.87:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yenāyasmā vakkali tenupasaṅkami.
sn22.87:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha robed up and, taking his bowl and robes, went to Venerable Vakkali.

sn22.87:2.2.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā vakkali bhagavantaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ. Disvāna mañcake samadhosi.
sn22.87:2.2.eng: Venerable Vakkali saw the Buddha coming off in the distance and stirred in his cot.

sn22.87:2.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ vakkaliṃ etadavoca:
sn22.87:2.3.eng: But the Buddha said to him,

sn22.87:2.4.eng: “It’s all right, Vakkali, don’t get up.

sn22.87:2.5.eng: There are some seats spread out, I will sit there.”

sn22.87:2.6.pli: Nisīdi bhagavā paññatte āsane. Nisajja kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ vakkaliṃ etadavoca:
sn22.87:2.6.eng: He sat on the seat spread out and said to Vakkali,

sn22.87:2.7.pli: “kacci te, vakkali, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīyaṃ, kacci dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti, no abhikkamanti; paṭikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no abhikkamo”ti?
sn22.87:2.7.eng: “I hope you’re keeping well, Vakkali; I hope you’re all right. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”

sn22.87:2.8.pli: “Na me, bhante, khamanīyaṃ, na yāpanīyaṃ; bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti; abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo”ti.
sn22.87:2.8.eng: “Sir, I’m not all right, I’m not getting by. My pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is apparent, not its fading.”

sn22.87:2.9.pli: “Kacci te, vakkali, na kiñci kukkuccaṃ, na koci vippaṭisāro”ti?
sn22.87:2.9.eng: “I hope you don’t have any remorse or regret?”

sn22.87:2.10.pli: “Taggha me, bhante, anappakaṃ kukkuccaṃ, anappako vippaṭisāro”ti.
sn22.87:2.10.eng: “Indeed, sir, I have no little remorse and regret.”

sn22.87:2.11.pli: “Kacci pana taṃ, vakkali, attā sīlato na upavadatī”ti?
sn22.87:2.11.eng: “I hope you have no reason to blame yourself when it comes to ethical conduct?”
sn22.87:2.11.comm: Normally “remorse” (kukkucca), as one of the five hindrances, is said to arise from a breach of ethics. This passage shows that it can be broader than that.

sn22.87:2.12.pli: “Na kho maṃ, bhante, attā sīlato upavadatī”ti.
sn22.87:2.12.eng: “No sir, I have no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct.”

sn22.87:2.13.pli: “No ce kira taṃ, vakkali, attā sīlato upavadati; atha kiñca te kukkuccaṃ ko ca vippaṭisāro”ti?
sn22.87:2.13.eng: “In that case, Vakkali, why do you have remorse and regret?”

sn22.87:2.14.pli: “Cirapaṭikāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamitukāmo, natthi ca me kāyasmiṃ tāvatikā balamattā, yāvatāhaṃ bhagavantaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkameyyan”ti.
sn22.87:2.14.eng: “For a long time I’ve wanted to go and see the Buddha, but I was physically too weak.”

sn22.87:3.1.pli: “Alaṃ, vakkali, kiṃ te iminā pūtikāyena diṭṭhena?
sn22.87:3.1.eng: “Enough, Vakkali! Why would you want to see this rotting body?
sn22.87:3.1.comm: The body is both a nest of disease and decay, as well as the site of pleasure and mindfulness in meditation. The Buddha did not look away from the foul aspects of the body, nor was he shy about depicting his own body in the same terms.

sn22.87:3.2.pli: Yo kho, vakkali, dhammaṃ passati so maṃ passati;
sn22.87:3.2.eng: One who sees the teaching sees me.
sn22.87:3.2.comm: Compare MN 28:28.5, “one who sees dependent origination sees the teaching”. If you understand the Dhamma you will understand the true nature of the Buddha, which is not his physical form (cf. the dhammakāya at DN 27:9.6).

sn22.87:3.3.pli: yo maṃ passati so dhammaṃ passati.
sn22.87:3.3.eng: One who sees me sees the teaching.

sn22.87:3.4.eng: Seeing the teaching, you see me.

sn22.87:3.5.eng: Seeing me, you see the teaching.

sn22.87:4.4.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vā taṃ sukhaṃ vā”ti?
sn22.87:4.4.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

sn22.87:4.6.pli: “Yaṃ panāniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, kallaṃ nu taṃ samanupassituṃ:
sn22.87:4.6.eng: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:

sn22.87:4.7.eng: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

sn22.87:4.18.eng: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’”

sn22.87:5.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ vakkaliṃ iminā ovādena ovaditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena gijjhakūṭo pabbato tena pakkāmi.
sn22.87:5.1.eng: And then, after giving Venerable Vakkali this advice, the Buddha got up from his seat and went to the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

sn22.87:5.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vakkali acirapakkantassa bhagavato upaṭṭhāke āmantesi:
sn22.87:5.2.eng: Then Venerable Vakkali addressed his carers,

sn22.87:5.3.pli: “etha maṃ, āvuso, mañcakaṃ āropetvā yena isigilipassaṃ kāḷasilā tenupasaṅkamatha.
sn22.87:5.3.eng: “Come on, reverends, lift my cot and take me to the Black Rock on the slopes of Isigili.

sn22.87:5.4.pli: Kathañhi nāma mādiso antaraghare kālaṃ kattabbaṃ maññeyyā”ti?
sn22.87:5.4.eng: For how on earth could one such as I imagine dying in an inhabited area!”
sn22.87:5.4.comm: Remember, he was staying in a potter’s shed, perhaps for access to medical care. But his heart was in the wilderness.

sn22.87:5.5.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato vakkalissa paṭissutvā āyasmantaṃ vakkaliṃ mañcakaṃ āropetvā yena isigilipassaṃ kāḷasilā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu.
sn22.87:5.5.eng: “Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants, and did as he asked.

sn22.87:5.6.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tañca rattiṃ tañca divāvasesaṃ gijjhakūṭe pabbate vihāsi.
sn22.87:5.6.eng: Meanwhile, the Buddha spent the rest of that night and day on Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

sn22.87:5.7.pli: Atha kho dve devatāyo abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ gijjhakūṭaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu …pe… ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu.
sn22.87:5.7.eng: Then, late at night, two glorious deities, lighting up the entire Vulture’s Peak, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side.

sn22.87:5.8.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho ekā devatā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

sn22.87:5.9.eng: “Sir, the mendicant Vakkali is intent on liberation!”

sn22.87:5.10.eng: And another deity said to him,

sn22.87:5.12.eng: This is what those deities said.

sn22.87:5.13.pli: Idaṃ vatvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyiṃsu.
sn22.87:5.13.eng: Then they bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right side, before vanishing right there.

sn22.87:6.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassā rattiyā accayena bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn22.87:6.1.eng: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

sn22.87:6.2.pli: “etha tumhe, bhikkhave, yena vakkali bhikkhu tenupasaṅkamatha; upasaṅkamitvā vakkaliṃ bhikkhuṃ evaṃ vadetha:
sn22.87:6.2.eng: “Come, mendicants, go to the mendicant Vakkali and tell him:

sn22.87:7.1.pli: ‘Suṇāvuso tvaṃ, vakkali, bhagavato vacanaṃ dvinnañca devatānaṃ.
sn22.87:7.1.eng: ‘Vakkali, hear the word of the Buddha and two deities.

sn22.87:7.2.pli: Imaṃ, āvuso, rattiṃ dve devatāyo abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ gijjhakūṭaṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu.
sn22.87:7.2.eng: Late last night, two glorious deities, lighting up the entire Vulture’s Peak, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side.

sn22.87:7.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho, āvuso, ekā devatā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca—

sn22.87:7.4.eng: “Sir, the mendicant Vakkali is intent on liberation!”

sn22.87:7.5.eng: The other deity said to him,

sn22.87:7.6.pli: so hi nūna, bhante, suvimutto vimuccissatīti.

sn22.87:7.7.pli: Bhagavā ca taṃ, āvuso vakkali, evamāha—

sn22.87:7.10.pli: Apāpakaṃ te maraṇaṃ bhavissati, apāpikā kālakiriyā’”ti.
sn22.87:7.10.eng: Your death will not be a bad one; your passing will not be a bad one.”’”

sn22.87:7.11.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paṭissutvā yenāyasmā vakkali tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ vakkaliṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn22.87:7.11.eng: “Yes, sir,” those monks replied. They went to Vakkali and said to him:

sn22.87:7.12.eng: “Vakkali, hear the word of the Buddha and two deities.”

sn22.87:8.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vakkali upaṭṭhāke āmantesi:

sn22.87:8.2.eng: “Please, reverends, help me off my cot.

sn22.87:8.3.pli: Kathañhi nāma mādiso ucce āsane nisīditvā tassa bhagavato sāsanaṃ sotabbaṃ maññeyyā”ti.
sn22.87:8.3.eng: For how on earth could one such as I presume to listen to the Buddha’s instructions sitting on a high seat?”

sn22.87:8.4.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato vakkalissa paṭissutvā āyasmantaṃ vakkaliṃ mañcakā oropesuṃ.
sn22.87:8.4.eng: “Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants, and helped him off his cot.

sn22.87:8.5.pli: “Imaṃ, āvuso, rattiṃ dve devatāyo abhikkantāya rattiyā …pe… ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu.
sn22.87:8.5.eng: They repeated what the Buddha had said.

sn22.87:8.6.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho, āvuso, ekā devatā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

sn22.87:8.10.pli: Bhagavā ca taṃ, āvuso vakkali, evamāha:

sn22.87:8.13.pli: Apāpakaṃ te maraṇaṃ bhavissati, apāpikā kālakiriyā’”ti.

sn22.87:8.14.pli: “Tena hāvuso, mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatha:
sn22.87:8.14.eng: Vakkali said, “Well then, reverends, in my name bow with your head at the Buddha’s feet. Say to him:

sn22.87:8.15.eng: ‘Sir, the mendicant Vakkali is sick, suffering, gravely ill.

sn22.87:8.16.eng: He bows with his head to your feet.’

sn22.87:8.19.eng: I have no doubt of that.

sn22.87:8.20.eng: I’m certain that what is impermanent is suffering.

sn22.87:8.21.pli: Yadaniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, natthi me tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vāti na vicikicchāmi.
sn22.87:8.21.eng: And I’m certain that I have no desire or greed or fondness for what is impermanent, suffering, and perishable.

sn22.87:8.25.pli: Yadaniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, natthi me tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vāti na vicikicchāmi.

sn22.87:8.30.pli: Yadaniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, natthi me tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vāti na vicikicchāmi.

sn22.87:8.32.eng: I have no doubt of that.

sn22.87:8.33.eng: I’m certain that what is impermanent is suffering.

sn22.87:8.34.pli: Yadaniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, natthi me tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vāti na vicikicchāmī’”ti.
sn22.87:8.34.eng: And I’m certain that I have no desire or greed or fondness for what is impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’”

sn22.87:8.35.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato vakkalissa paṭissutvā pakkamiṃsu.
sn22.87:8.35.eng: “Yes, reverend,” those monks replied, and left.

sn22.87:8.36.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vakkali acirapakkantesu tesu bhikkhūsu satthaṃ āharesi.
sn22.87:8.36.eng: And then, not long after those mendicants had left, Venerable Vakkali committed suicide.
sn22.87:8.36.comm: Compare Godhika at SN 4.23:2.3, Channa at MN 144:13.11 = SN 35.87, and notes at MN 145:5.32 and Bu Pj 3:2.49.1 = SN 54.9.

sn22.87:9.1.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn22.87:9.1.eng: Then those mendicants went up to the Buddha and told him Vakkali’s message.

sn22.87:9.8.pli: Yadaniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, natthi me tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vāti na vicikicchāmi.

sn22.87:9.15.pli: Yadaniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, natthi me tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vāti na vicikicchāmī’”ti.

sn22.87:10.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,

sn22.87:10.2.eng: “Come, mendicants, let’s go to the Black Rock on the slopes of Isigili,

sn22.87:10.3.eng: where Vakkali, the gentleman, committed suicide.”

sn22.87:10.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

sn22.87:10.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sambahulehi bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ yena isigilipassaṃ kāḷasilā tenupasaṅkami.
sn22.87:10.5.eng: Then the Buddha together with several mendicants went to the Black Rock on the slopes of Isigili.

sn22.87:10.6.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ vakkaliṃ dūratova mañcake vivattakkhandhaṃ semānaṃ.
sn22.87:10.6.eng: The Buddha saw Vakkali off in the distance on his cot, lying with aggregates cast off.
sn22.87:10.6.comm: Vivatta (or vivaṭṭa) often means “cast off”, as in “the fetters” (vivattayi saṁyojanaṁ) or the “veil” (vivaṭṭacchada). Here it describes the dead monk’s body after attaining final Nibbana.

sn22.87:11.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena dhūmāyitattaṃ timirāyitattaṃ gacchateva purimaṃ disaṃ, gacchati pacchimaṃ disaṃ, gacchati uttaraṃ disaṃ, gacchati dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ, gacchati uddhaṃ disaṃ, gacchati adho disaṃ, gacchati anudisaṃ.
sn22.87:11.1.eng: Now at that time a cloud of black smoke was moving east, west, north, south, above, below, and in-between.

sn22.87:11.2.eng: The Buddha said to the mendicants,

sn22.87:11.3.pli: “passatha no tumhe, bhikkhave, etaṃ dhūmāyitattaṃ timirāyitattaṃ gacchateva purimaṃ disaṃ …pe… gacchati anudisan”ti.
sn22.87:11.3.eng: “Mendicants, do you see that cloud of black smoke moving east, west, north, south, above, below, and in-between?”

sn22.87:11.5.pli: “Eso kho, bhikkhave, māro pāpimā vakkalissa kulaputtassa viññāṇaṃ samanvesati:
sn22.87:11.5.eng: “That’s Māra the Wicked searching for Vakkali’s consciousness, wondering:

sn22.87:11.7.pli: Appatiṭṭhitena ca, bhikkhave, viññāṇena vakkali kulaputto parinibbuto”ti.
sn22.87:11.7.eng: But since his consciousness is not established, Vakkali is quenched.”
